trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Batch PowerShell cmdlets | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Batch PowerShell cmdlets | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Introduces the Azure PowerShell cmdlets used to manage the Azure Batch service
trans-unit.target: Introduces the Azure PowerShell cmdlets used to manage the Azure Batch service

trans-unit.source: This article is a quick introduction to the Azure PowerShell cmdlets you can use to manage your Batch accounts and get information about your Batch jobs, tasks, and other details.
trans-unit.target: This article is a quick introduction to the Azure PowerShell cmdlets you can use to manage your Batch accounts and get information about your Batch jobs, tasks, and other details.

trans-unit.source: For detailed cmdlet syntax, type get-help or see the Azure Batch cmdlet reference.
trans-unit.target: For detailed cmdlet syntax, type get-help or see the Azure Batch cmdlet reference.

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell - See How to install and configure Azure PowerShell for prerequisites and download and installation instructions.
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell - See How to install and configure Azure PowerShell for prerequisites and download and installation instructions.

trans-unit.source: Batch cmdlets were introduced in version 0.8.10 and later versions.
trans-unit.target: Batch cmdlets were introduced in version 0.8.10 and later versions.

trans-unit.source: The Batch cmdlets were updated to use the general availability API in version 0.9.6.
trans-unit.target: The Batch cmdlets were updated to use the general availability API in version 0.9.6.

trans-unit.source: Use standard procedures to start Azure PowerShell and <linkText>connect to your Azure subscriptions</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Use standard procedures to start Azure PowerShell and <linkText>connect to your Azure subscriptions</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Additionally:
trans-unit.target: Additionally:

trans-unit.source: Select Azure subscription - If you have more than subscription, select a subscription:
trans-unit.target: Select Azure subscription - If you have more than subscription, select a subscription:

trans-unit.source: Switch to AzureResourceManage mode - The Batch cmdlets ship in the Azure Resource Manager module.
trans-unit.target: Switch to AzureResourceManage mode - The Batch cmdlets ship in the Azure Resource Manager module.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Using Windows PowerShell with Resource Manager</linkText><title></title> for details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Using Windows PowerShell with Resource Manager</linkText><title></title> for details.

trans-unit.source: To use this module, run the <linkText>Switch-AzureMode</linkText><title></title> cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: To use this module, run the <linkText>Switch-AzureMode</linkText><title></title> cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: Register with the Batch provider namespace (one-time operation) - Before you can manage your Batch accounts, you must register with the Batch provider namespace.
trans-unit.target: Register with the Batch provider namespace (one-time operation) - Before you can manage your Batch accounts, you must register with the Batch provider namespace.

trans-unit.source: This operation only needs to be performed once per subscription.
trans-unit.target: This operation only needs to be performed once per subscription.

trans-unit.source: You can use Azure PowerShell cmdlets to create and manage Batch accounts and keys.
trans-unit.target: You can use Azure PowerShell cmdlets to create and manage Batch accounts and keys.

trans-unit.source: New-AzureBatchAccount creates a new Batch account in a specified resource group.
trans-unit.target: New-AzureBatchAccount creates a new Batch account in a specified resource group.

trans-unit.source: If you do not already have a resource group, create one by running the New-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet, specifying one of the Azure regions in the Location parameter.
trans-unit.target: If you do not already have a resource group, create one by running the New-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet, specifying one of the Azure regions in the Location parameter.

trans-unit.source: (You can find available regions for different Azure resources by running <linkText>Get-AzureLocation</linkText><title></title>.)
trans-unit.target: (You can find available regions for different Azure resources by running <linkText>Get-AzureLocation</linkText><title></title>.)

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Then, create a new Batch account account in the resource group, also specifying an account name for <account_name> and a location where the Batch service is available. Creating the account can take several minutes to complete. For example:
trans-unit.target: Then, create a new Batch account account in the resource group, also specifying an account name for <account_name> and a location where the Batch service is available. Creating the account can take several minutes to complete. For example:

trans-unit.source: The Batch account name must be unique to Azure, contain between 3 and 24 characters, and use lowercase letters and numbers only.
trans-unit.target: The Batch account name must be unique to Azure, contain between 3 and 24 characters, and use lowercase letters and numbers only.

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureBatchAccountKeys shows the access keys associated with an Azure Batch account.
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureBatchAccountKeys shows the access keys associated with an Azure Batch account.

trans-unit.source: For example, run the following to get the primary and secondary keys of the account you created.
trans-unit.target: For example, run the following to get the primary and secondary keys of the account you created.

trans-unit.source: New-AzureBatchAccountKey generates a new primary or secondary account key for an Azure Batch account.
trans-unit.target: New-AzureBatchAccountKey generates a new primary or secondary account key for an Azure Batch account.

trans-unit.source: For example, to generate a new primary key for your Batch account, type:
trans-unit.target: For example, to generate a new primary key for your Batch account, type:

trans-unit.source: To generate a new secondary key, specify "Secondary" for the KeyType parameter.
trans-unit.target: To generate a new secondary key, specify "Secondary" for the KeyType parameter.

trans-unit.source: You have to regenerate the primary and secondary keys separately.
trans-unit.target: You have to regenerate the primary and secondary keys separately.

trans-unit.source: Remove-AzureBatchAccount deletes a Batch account.
trans-unit.target: Remove-AzureBatchAccount deletes a Batch account.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, confirm you want to remove the account.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, confirm you want to remove the account.

trans-unit.source: Account removal can take some time to complete.
trans-unit.target: Account removal can take some time to complete.

trans-unit.source: Use cmdlets such as Get-AzureBatchJob, Get-AzureBatchTask, and Get-AzureBatchPool to query for entities created under a Batch account.
trans-unit.target: Use cmdlets such as Get-AzureBatchJob, Get-AzureBatchTask, and Get-AzureBatchPool to query for entities created under a Batch account.

trans-unit.source: To use these cmdlets, you first need to create an AzureBatchContext object to store your account name and keys:
trans-unit.target: To use these cmdlets, you first need to create an AzureBatchContext object to store your account name and keys:

trans-unit.source: You pass this context into cmdlets that interact with the Batch service by using the BatchContext parameter.
trans-unit.target: You pass this context into cmdlets that interact with the Batch service by using the BatchContext parameter.

trans-unit.source: By default, the account's primary key is used for authentication, but you can explicitly select the key to use by changing your BatchAccountContext object’s KeyInUse property: $context.KeyInUse = "Secondary".
trans-unit.target: By default, the account's primary key is used for authentication, but you can explicitly select the key to use by changing your BatchAccountContext object’s KeyInUse property: $context.KeyInUse = "Secondary".

trans-unit.source: As an example, use Get-AzureBatchPools to find your pools.
trans-unit.target: As an example, use Get-AzureBatchPools to find your pools.

trans-unit.source: By default this queries for all pools under your account, assuming you already stored the BatchAccountContext object in $context:
trans-unit.target: By default this queries for all pools under your account, assuming you already stored the BatchAccountContext object in $context:

trans-unit.source: You can supply an OData filter using the Filter parameter to find only the objects you’re interested in.
trans-unit.target: You can supply an OData filter using the Filter parameter to find only the objects you’re interested in.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can find all pools with ids starting with “myPool”:
trans-unit.target: For example, you can find all pools with ids starting with “myPool”:

trans-unit.source: This method is not as flexible as using “Where-Object” in a local pipeline.
trans-unit.target: This method is not as flexible as using “Where-Object” in a local pipeline.

trans-unit.source: However, the query gets sent to the Batch service directly so that all filtering happens on the server side, saving Internet bandwidth.
trans-unit.target: However, the query gets sent to the Batch service directly so that all filtering happens on the server side, saving Internet bandwidth.

trans-unit.source: An alternative to an OData filter is to use the Id parameter.
trans-unit.target: An alternative to an OData filter is to use the Id parameter.

trans-unit.source: To query for a specific pool with id "myPool":
trans-unit.target: To query for a specific pool with id "myPool":

trans-unit.source: The Id parameter supports only full-id search, not wildcards or OData-style filters.
trans-unit.target: The Id parameter supports only full-id search, not wildcards or OData-style filters.

trans-unit.source: Batch cmdlets can leverage the PowerShell pipeline to send data between cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: Batch cmdlets can leverage the PowerShell pipeline to send data between cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: This has the same effect as specifying a parameter but makes listing multiple entities easier.
trans-unit.target: This has the same effect as specifying a parameter but makes listing multiple entities easier.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can find all tasks under your account:
trans-unit.target: For example, you can find all tasks under your account:

trans-unit.source: By default, each cmdlet returns a maximum of 1000 objects.
trans-unit.target: By default, each cmdlet returns a maximum of 1000 objects.

trans-unit.source: If you reach this limit, you can either refine your filter to bring back fewer objects, or explicitly set a maximum using the MaxCount parameter.
trans-unit.target: If you reach this limit, you can either refine your filter to bring back fewer objects, or explicitly set a maximum using the MaxCount parameter.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: To remove the upper bound, set MaxCount to 0 or less.
trans-unit.target: To remove the upper bound, set MaxCount to 0 or less.
